title: Helldivers
summary: Set in a dystopian future, players fight to protect "Super Earth" where a managed democracy has mussed the lines between military and government rule. We are losing the war, and the HELLDIVERS are the last line of defense against three invading enemy species.
reviews: While it may not look like much on the surface, Helldivers has a hell of a lot going on once players dig in, and being a disposable interstellar trooper raiding death planets has never been more perfectly captured than it is here.

With its sledgehammer humor and clever blend of stealth and action, Helldivers is a lot smarter than a passing glance might have you believe. It’s a game in which life is cheap but the deaths aren’t, where carelessness gets you turned into kibble, and sustained battle will leave you with an empty gun and a horde of pissed off monsters.
It isn’t the prettiest game you can play on PS4, PS3 or Vita, but Helldivers is one of the most exhilarating, and you’ll get all three versions for the price of one.

At a first glance Helldivers might look simplistic and repetitive, but
it does not take long before you realize how deep and enjoyable the
core mechanics are. If you want an easy to understand yet challenging
cooperative shooter, you cannot do better than Helldivers.
Helldivers isn’t game that has come out of nowhere, but it is one that has fully exceeded expectations.
Fast-paced and humorous with deep combat, this space romp should be required in every PS4 owner's library.
Right in the sweet spot between being fun and challenging.
While the maps and enemies could be more varied and interesting, there’s no denying that the gameplay is stellar, rewarding you for working closely with your teammates and punishing you otherwise.

Unrelenting and brutal, Helldivers delivers fast-paced combat, epic standoffs and a comical approach to death. Its enemies are varied, powerful and a constant threat to the players. While the full impact of the larger multiplayer experience remains to be seen, it still adds a nice little scratch to the progress itch.
Helldivers may not look that spectacular, but it certainly plays that way. A hardcore shoot 'em up that rewards tactical thinking and teamwork.

Helldivers has everything we expected in an Arrowhead game: it's fun, it's challenging and highly rewarding. It is best played with friends as you can annoy them for the sake of fun. The social component of the global war effort is well implemented and motivates players to engage in it. Highly recommended.

You can play Helldivers alone but there’s not much point to it, because it’s the co-op that’s teeming with dramatic moments that make this twin-stick shooter easy to fall in love with. Not for a lifetime maybe, but for a dozen evenings of heroism, sacrifice and brotherhood in arms. [05/2015, p.52]
If you can find good company that will help you throughout the online campaign, here you'll experience one of the best co-op games ever created.

If you are looking for a game that you can pick up and play a few rounds on your lunch break, or spend a few hours playing with friends while laughing, strategizing, and blasting your way to victory, I’d say quelling the menacing alien forces is well worth the enlistment price.

Helldivers is an excellent mix of tactics and action. The freedom it offers through weapons and Stratagem-skills makes it possible for everybody to create their own way of playing this game. The difficulty level is nice and high, which makes the co-op experience even more intense. This game might look a bit generic, the gameplay is so much fun that you won't even notice.

Even after the unlocks dry up, the challenge and camaraderie that Helldivers offers makes it hard not to attempt "just one more mission" with your friends, a proposition made all the more enticing by the inclusion of four-player couch co-op. I still don't know how the community-driven galactic campaign will shake out over the coming weeks, but contributing to the larger war effort is just one more welcome excuse to enlist.
Things can go from excellent to utter crap in mere seconds, and entire missions can be lost easily, but that’s part of the fun.
A badass little blaster that's not afraid to be hardcore and treat you like a whiny little child, Helldivers is most fun when you and your teammates work together.

Its strategy, action and excitement on cooperative mode with friendly fire helps us to forget that Helldivers' procedural design results in repetitive matches. If you are looking for a game with difficult challenges and a great time with friends then this is the game you're looking for.
The amount of depth, coupled with the potentially super high rewards for good players, makes this a diamond in the rough. For those of the correct disposition, Helldivers will be an absolute gem.
Will you do YOUR part, citizen? You should. [May 2015, p80]
The upgrade paths and gear-gating lend genuine longevity. [May 2015, p.94]
Despite those small story issues, Helldivers conquers its fair share of stars.
An utterly superb cooperative game: one that makes you work together not just to win, but to survive more than a few minutes.

As long as you find capable team players this is a fun romp, while with the wrong “mates” it becomes a tedious mess. That aside it lacks a little refinement here and there and mission variety – nothing critical though.

Helldivers measures its brutal difficulty against a dehumanizing military and political complex that results in humor and violence, both about as subtle and hard-hitting as a freight train. Such is the price of liberty, paid in full with a pile of shell casings and the sickening splat of another expendable soldier.
As long as the network issues can be sorted out, I have a lot of great expectations for Helldivers. This can easily be one of the most fun co-op experiences all year, for both indie and AAA titles.

Helldivers is one of the new stars of the PSN, no doubt about it. This game may look average at first sight, but its simple but deep systems, its numerous originalities and its advanced cooperative gameplay makes it simply irresistible and totally addictive.

It's a bit chaotic and the visuals won't win any awards in the near future, but if you don't mind these things, Helldivers turns out to be a pretty enjoyable top-down shooter with some strategy elements thrown in for good measure.

Helldivers offers plenty of challenges and a great excuse to play with others, and that is when the game is at its best. There is a nice campaign built around the carnage that offers a sense of accomplishment, too, that makes the difficulty worthwhile.
Helldivers is simple in concept, but demanding and very engaging. Hours of fun guaranteed.
Chaos, frenzy and a great cooperative action game. Helldivers is an awesome game for those who want a top-down shooter to play with friends.
If you are looking for a co-op title fun and direct, Helldivers is what you are looking for. It innovates on its genre and does almost everything right. Much better played with friends.
Helldivers works as a well designed cooperative experience in PS4, PS3 and PS Vita. A great game with tons of content that will bring you many hours of space combat gameplay.

After being left disappointed many a time by previous local multiplayer games the PlayStation 4 has had to offer, Helldivers is a breath of fresh air providing short bursts of explosive action that’s both strategic and enjoyable.

Gameplay is quick, satisfying, and often chaotic, and the stratagem system gives the action a unique identity. The only question mark here is the one that hangs over the title's community, which must be sustained if the shooter is to realise its impressive potential.
A well designed, challenging and entertaining shooter that's best appreciated as a multiplayer game. More variety in mission types would help it feel less of a grind, however.
Helldivers is the kind of game all co-op titles should strive to be. Not only does it offer a very rewarding top-down twin-stick shooter experience, but it's co-op goes beyond your own game.
Helldivers is a solid twin-stick shooter that will force you to use your brain, not only your pad. Addictive with friends, boring when played alone. Give it a chance: you might be surprised.

Imperfect as it may be, Helldivers' focus on the cooperation of a small team looking out for each other against oppressive waves of enemies elevates it from what would have been a fun and challenging shooter, to a game that now sits at the top of my list of how I plan to spend many future evenings: with a gun in hand, my allies at my back, and a broad smile on my face.

Helldivers has some fine cooperative cooperative mechanics, but has also flaws. Visuals are not so next-gen, but first of all is too repetitive and grinding prone, even though we have a great multiplayer mode, the Galactic Campaign.

Helldivers is fun and engaging, and the "galactic warfare" theme adds interesting elements to the global cooperation. On the other hand, even if the character progression will keep the players interested for a while, the repetitive missions will loose their grip.
With some great cooperative mechanics, Helldivers is better when playing with friends, but repetitive missions and maps lacks experience.

Helldivers is at its greatest when playing with friends in short bursts. If played alone, or over long periods of time, weaknesses like the small number of abilities to choose from, repetitive battles and weapons, and overly-similar missions start to show.
A great and fun arcade shooter. A little gem that needs to be supported and expanded by Arrowhead. The game presents some really nice ideas in a too-tiny, and repetitive, universe.
Helldivers is a fun romp through a tedious space system...The rapid co-op action makes for a great way to kill a few hours with your friends, but continued travels expose repetitive maps.

Some - those that love a bit of pain in their games, to make the reward even sweeter - might be truly bewitched by this charming game, especially if they play it with the right company. All the others will find in Helldivers a fun and refreshing experience, one that's capable of adding something unique to a well known formula crowded with glorious precursors. It might not be fully on par with the best ever in its genre, but don't hesitate to give it a chance if you dig this kind of shooter.

Excellent co-op top-down action offers a very satisfactory gameplay focused on the endless bloodbath and well designed, but slightly stereotypical tasks. With the right bunch of teammates it will attract your attention for long hours. But join the wrong group and you will feel like the hell broke loose.
Helldivers is at first a fresh, rewarding, challenging experience that stands up to any other game in terms of quality.
Despite all this, with the raucous chaos of multiplayer mode, Helldivers is still capable of being engrossing for long periods.

Helldivers is a typical co-op twin stick-shooter. The multiplayer is challenging and makes up for the inconsistent pacing, the boring surroundings and repetitive missions. On your own, Helldivers is a very frustrating experience with big ambitions but too little depth of content.
The only good bug is a dead bug... Starship Troopers has become a (very hard) third person shooter.
Travel the universe and meet hordes of interesting alien species, then shoot them repeatedly in the face - with friends.

Helldivers is an enjoyable game, especially white playing its co-op mode that allows playing with three friends. It's not very good playing solo and it's much harder, enough to put average players in hardship. However, it has quite a lack of variety when it comes to mission objectives and its gameplay mechanics aren't very good either.

Helldivers’ metagame campaign and variety of gameplay are more than enough to keep you entertained, but only players with a tight-knit group of co-op buddies will be able to get the most from the experience.
Although the gameplay and mission structure quickly becomes repetitive, Helldivers offers hours of entertaining co-op twin-stick action in a universe that's begging to be further developed.
helldivers is like baby from starship troopers and warhammer 40k , fun and addictive but also...... PREPARE TO DIE.......... ALOT !!!! with unlimited replay value, it cant go wrong for 19.99

By FAR the most fun i've had in a multiplayer game on my PS4 since i bought it, and for $20? Devs should call the police because this a STEAL! The stratagem system is awesome, the weapons feel diverse and the sounds, oh my god the sound of a machinegun spinning up and spewing death and mayhem in every direction.. If you haven't picked this game up already, treat yourself. And the developers are in tune with the community with constant feedback through their subreddit and i guess they have forums as well. 10/10

Easy to learn, hard to master. This game shines in multi. Possibly one of the best co-op games I've ever played. The theme is the satiric progressive/expansionist futuristic society, think Starship Troopers!

Total blast. Baldur's Gate meets Starship Troopers. Absolutely addicting and the best $20 I've spent on a game in recent memory. So much fun and seemingly unlimited playability. I've found myself playing this exclusively now for a couple weeks. Who knew spreading democracy throughout the universe could be so fun.  The online co-op is where its at. Link up as a foursome and have at some bug killing. Lots of fun weapons and level ups. I hope there's a sequel. Game rocks.

Great twin stick shooter... the most enjoyable multiplayer experience ive had on PS4 thus far... unforgiving difficulty curve simple but great mechanics... 15 hours of enjoyment atm, great value for money...

I never expected that this game would be so much fun. Helldivers is very challenging and strategical. It is the best COOP game I've ever played. Only bad thing I found was the internet connection that was sometimes difficult to connect to other players. Other aspects are fine. Gameplay is superb. A bit repetitive once you played for a while, but acceptable with this low price. You can't expect the game to have huge content like AAA game 60s title anyway. I really like to see  this game evolve in the future. There are a lot of rooms to improve.

Excellent twin stick shooter with co-op play. Something ive always wanted. Having 3 of my buddies join and taking on a hell dive challenge is a blast. Game really places and emphasis on co-op play, i.e. buddy can reload your rocket launcher for you making the reload time much faster. Excellent way to reward players for co-op play. Also im glad friendly fire is on. Makes it that much more challenging, and ofcourse funny. Good variety of enemies. I thought i would move on from this game within 2 weeks, but the game play was solid enough to keep me around.
This game... I started to believe in games again.. I could write things forever  but no, i want to leave a comment for this glorious game and go back and play.
So much fun to play. This is such a great example of easy to play and hard to master. Go in Solo, if you have the skills. Check out the Lvl12 solo runs on youtube.

Really...really...really...good. I love this game. It is very satisfying to punch in the various codes to summon items and gear, which was something that had me worried before i purchased it. It looks good, is fun and has a satirical humor. Pick it up if you enjoyed Diablo, Dead nation, Renegade ops, Mortal Kombat, Commando, Contra, Warcraft, Dark souls etc. just get it, you shant be dissatisfied(the vita version is good, but a little cumbersome control wise, though not overtly{for me anyways}.)

You'll die. A lot! Cause there is a myriad of stuffs that can, and will, kill you - friends, foes, gear - and it is all part of the fun. I think there is a whole lot of others that thinks this reminds them of this being a baby spawned from Starship troopers and Warhammer 40k, and I'll have to say: I agree.
Its a good game with a good "starship troopers" storie!

I have 50+ hours in this game and still enjoying every moment of it. You can technically play it as a single player, but having or finding a good team and working together to complete a "Hell Dive" difficulty mission with 3 stars is very satisfying. I love how all the players are playing together in a common real-time galactic campaign. Any independent accomplishment will give you the feeling that you are contributing to the whole community. Which is probably the reason why the people you meet online are mostly friendly.

HONEST REVIEW: This game does what it aims to do, and does it well. No more, and no less. If you're looking for a complex story, good character development and a well thought out single player plotline, you won't find it here. If you ARE looking for an hour or two to burn with a couple friends playing a strategic, well made twin-stick shooter, and having a blast doing it, you've downloaded the right game.

It reminds me of Destiny just in an overhead shooter form. I just wished there was more of a single player aspect, not everybody can always play online with a group of friends. Mechanics are solid & the graphics are pretty great overall considering it's modest budget. If you're looking for a challenging shooter to play with friends, this is a great place to start.

Excellent twin-stick co-op. I didn't understand why they employed D-Pad combos to execute stratagems at first, but once you're past training and in a real mission, it adds a sense of urgency to the game. Nice look, controls are tight, and good value. Best of all, the difficulty is no walk-in-the park. Challenging, but not frustrating. With all the money I flushed down the toilet on recent lack-luster AAA releases, this is a breath of fresh air. I must inform you that I am a little biased toward twin-stickers, though. This goes all the way back to my youth and spending inordinate amounts of time and money on Robotron 2084. I'm only registering a score because I won't be able to post this review without one. I'm sick of assigning numbers. Numbers are for calculators.
Sadly, Helldivers lacks to many design flaws to be a good game.

Yes this game a is a top down twin stick shooter with remnants of Starship Troopers but, it's so much more. The depth of perks, stratagems and coop battles make this a game the best of it's genre. There is an abundance of features to this game that make it a game to keep you and your friends playing for months to come. It's a refreshing title that brings a ton of fun to the Playstation family. It's nice to have more couch coop games as well, when there is such a small selection to choose from.
Me and 2 of my friends bought the game due to high ratings and recommendation online and played a few hours (now at level 7).

It may seem just like another mix of games that you've already played before but Helldivers is something of its own. It has tons of replay ability, progression, and addictiveness. I'm sure you've heard that Helldivers shines brightest with friends. Give this one a try!

Helldivers, whilst an enjoyably frantic multiplayer experience, is an endless grind with randomised maps and no campaign structure whatsoever. I have played for nearly 25hrs in my quest for the level 25 gold trophy, and the game is very much either one of two things: an outright 'kill 100's of enemies on tiny map' horde mode OR 'survive doing fusebox busywork objectives on bigger maps' horde mode. If you want to grind experience points, you play horde mode maps only on double xp 'event' days. If you want equipment upgrades, you try to find people willing to farm "samples" (collectibles) scattered around the bigger maps. THAT'S ALL the game has to offer!

My 2 sisters and I loved playing this game. Its so easy to play 3 player local co-op. You soon get used to Friendly fire and how to call in air drops. We enjoyed playing Dead Nation, but the the graphics on HellDivers are so much better which really adds to the game.

defenatly a 10/10 if you play with freinds. when your low on ammo waiting for extraction while completly surrounded by enemis and some one sacrifices them selfs so the others can get away. those are the moments in games that are the best. it is definatly not a sp game.

Yea, good game, well worth the price (small compare to other games came out around the same time). Who would've thought that friendly fire in a top down shooter will change the game so much, it gets you thinking about forming a line, how best to move as a team etc. Haven't played the game much (only got to level 5), best moments were times when I saved teammates with shots that narrowly misses them and got the mob that was melee them.

Arrowhead's Magicka roots are definitely apparent, and that's a good thing because they sure know how to make friendly fire hilarious, even when the difficulty is as high as this game. Recommend it to anyone with even a passing interest in twin stick shooters.

People can't be too particular! This is the real GAME! FUN is its core. After some controversies on some PS exclusive games, this one is finally an epic one!  I have some much fun with my friends playing it! You don't want to miss it!

So my friends asks me how is "Helldivers".. My answer? Frustratingly FUN.. It is one of those games you cannot lose focus. There are things you can unlock by leveling up and there are things you can only get by beating certain planets on certain difficulty. There are also perks you can unlock by using research points. Overall this game is fun. Missions usually take about 10-20 mins, this is based on missions up to a "7" difficulty. So after a mission you see that it took 15 mins but it felt like forever! BUT you want more! I'd say if you are a little bored right now, give it a try you won't regret it.

An incredible co-op experiences that rewards communication, focus, and wit. This game is truly genius in the form of the Stratagems feature, which allows you to deploy air-dropped weapons like Turrets, APCs, Tanks, and more. The game is BRUTAL too, one mistake and you've accidentally killed a teammate, or gotten killed by an enemy. I can't wait to see how much more content the developers add.

It's like if Destiny were top down and actually fun.  But seriously, this is a blast in co-op.  I personally would skip if you weren't planning on playing it with friends, as the missions get repetitive.

I have been waiting for this game since November 2013 telling myself this is the first Indie game I had ever been looking for ever.  Good God is it fun and a breath of fresh air!!!  Thank you Arrowhead for making such a fun and different experience while keeping a very high level of graphical quality!

-ATTENTION ALL UNDECIDED PS users--ignore ALL ratings under 3..(esp ALL ZEROs) they are frustrated Xbox fanboys, or haters for who knows why.. I wish meta critic would fix this immature crap and limit the flAme scorers.........
If you like playing tough dual sticks shooters with some friends, this is the game you need.

Somebody finally nailed a co-op dual stick shooter. Missions are short at about 15 minutes that it doesn't really matter so much if you get a crappy team. Lots of fun just working together to complete the objectives. Surprising amount of depth that will keep you playing for a long time with lots of interesting weapons and perks to unlock to keep it fresh. Biggest criticism is that matching making is terrible. You have to scroll through lots of full games and fail to connect to a game a lot to get matched. Some of the unlocks are useless and some are overpowered. Hopefully these get patched. Single player is not very fun. I can't recommend this game enough.

Boy, this game is an evil piece of... software. Don't expect the game to show you any courtesy or help you in any way, it's tough as nails. But when you beat a mission, you feel like a badass! Not for the faint of heart!

Fantastic game, but very much multiplayer-centric. It isn't much fun solo, but it is so much fun with friends. I have to knock it down to an 8 for now, though, because of matchmaking issues. First of all you can't currently join a game if a friend is hosting it on a different device (so PS4 to PS Vita, for example), though apparently that does work with randoms. Even when you're on the same platform it sometimes produces an error message when you try to join even if there is room for you. The game will seem to think they are not playing even though they are, or that the game is full when it isn't. You have to wait a few minutes, go back to the main menu, then go back in and you'll be able to join the game. I hope they can resolve these issues soon, but even with them this game is just so much fun. Highly recommended.

Every game I play either at our place our online, something hilarious/tragic/both happens, everyone laughs out loud, and someone catches themselves saying out loud something to the effect of "Man, this game is awesome!" There's just something about the joy and craziness of this game, and I can't stop playing it. So looking forward to Magicka 2!

There is a ton of reviews on this, I'll keep it short. It's a great game, very fun, the co opt works fantastic. It could use more stories and varied missions though. It you like Diablo and Starship troopers with a bunch of Warhammer 40K thrown it, you'll  love it.

Refreshing gameplay in the form of a top down shooter, although it has a steep learning curve at first, once you get used to the controls it's hard to put down, coop is satisfying and the banter of "Freedom" and "Liberty" adds a humorous touch to it all.
I bought this game, and it's what i have imagined. TOOO FUN!
Automatic weapons don't shoot with some DS4 controllers, the dev's said they won't fix it, suggesting to people to buy another controller, obviously 60$ of incompetancy tax.
I'll keep this as quick and benifical to you (the reader) as I possible can.

Helldrivers parece que ha sacado lo mejor de otros juegos para hacer una combinación maravillosa, la campaña tradicional ha sido dejada de lado para meterse de lleno en la experiencia multijugador, ya que jugar de forma individual es lo mismo pero sin compañeros de equipo.

For right noe, i can only give this game a 7. I have been waiting for this game since i first heard about it coming to PS Vita in February 2013. So far I have only put about an hour into it on PS4, and after only 4 missions, i like the gameplay and mechanics. I love twin stick shooters, so this was a day one purchase for me, however, as of now I'm not a big fan of the short missions. The first 4 missions that I have played have all consisted of completing 1 objective, like activating a SAM launcher, and then moving to the extraction point,  and ending the mission. I do like the drop in/drop out multi-player, but so far of the missions I've played, players drop in right at the end, and dont really get to experience anything. So for now I've had to switch my lobby to private to stop from ruining everyone else's experience of dropping into my game when I have already completed the objective. I really hope that the more that I play, the better the missions will get, so that it really gives me an incentive to play multi-player. I'm sure it will, bit in the early missions its just not worth it to force would be teammates to join in just to view a loading screen.

This is one of the best exclusives on PS4.  There are some bugs right now, but overall its tremendously fun with friends or pubs, and offers really different gameplay styles for solo play.  Many build options, lots of hilarious accidents.  Spend the money you save on this 20 dollar gem and get a headset!  I've been playing since release and I'm hopelessly and joyously addicted.

Helldivers , where do I start ! Top down twin sticks, yes. Unlockable tech tree that spans many hours, check. Engaging co op experience, yes. Inventive methods of calling in support packs, yes. Tower defence elements laced throughout, oh yes! A live dynamic battlefield where your choices make a difference in the galactic war! Also check. This game is the bee's knees! If you like shooting and dying and calling in air supports and probably also reviving people you're in luck. If you don't like fun and chew nails for a living then maybe you should pass this up ! Single player exists but only because it has to. Grab some pals or randos and let's save the Galaxy !
WARNING!!! This game is the biggest steaming pile of crap ever released on PSN.

As a couple that has little time for video games these days, my girlfriend and I look for simple co-op games we can play in our downtime.  From the videos I watched Helldivers seemed like the sort of run-n-gun shooter we would enjoy.  Some mindless bug splattering nonsense that we can switch off our brains for and enjoy.  Sadly this was NOT the case.

Another overrated indie game without anything interesting about it, bad for SP gaming, no story, same as every online centric game out there, and you only need one of those to play, so this is just extra"fat" that serves no purpose. There are much better indies out there, including on the PS4, and some of them were free on PS+ so no need to waste money on this.
Log in.  Go to the multiplayer pad.  Shoot things.  For Democracy!  For freedom!!  For liberty!!!  For the sound bugs make when they pop!!  I am enjoying myself  :)
Yet again Sony have let us down. We had a terrible xmas on ps+ a terrible New Year and now an awful February. Feb's free games list is headlined by this outdated, mess of a game.

Easily the best multiplayer game I have experienced on the PS4.  It stresses teamwork, and the degree to which you can adjust your loadout to compliment your team entering a mission is fantastic (the number of stratagems and weapons and perks, along with the implications  of various upgrades is very impressive).  In one game, I can stress offensive firepower, lumbering around in gatling & missile toting walkers....in another I can play a support role, keeping the heavy hitters alive by healing them , dropping mines and turrets to block enemy movement and jumping via jet pack where I' needed.  OR I can distract enemy patrols with deploy and forget noise makers, recon the area with UAVs or make my game a priority for other players looking to join a match.  It's brilliant.   Play "smart" and as a unit and you can tackle the hardest objectives..providing covering fire from a IFV turret while team mates dismount and complete the objective.

This is a very cool game.  All of the games in this genre seem repetitive but at least this one has a large number of upgrades and options.  The co op is a lot of fun and intense.  There is nothing "easy" about the game which is great.  Even on "Medium" levels with 4 players you will die.  Well worth the 17.99 I paid.

Set in a dystopian future, players fight to protect "Super Earth" where a managed democracy has mussed the lines between military and government rule. We are losing the war, and the HELLDIVERS are the last line of defense against three invading enemy species.
Boring, repetitive, and unoriginal. Ammo empties so fast. Ripped off a warhammer series w/ logos and character design. Also warhammer did a way better two stick shooter years ago. Complete trash

I'm giving it a 6/10 due to respect for the decent gameplay, graphics, and design. I, however, did not enjoy it and just find these top-down coop shooters that much fun. If you like these kinds of games, it might be decent.

The games network protocol are all p2p with small updates done to the community stats done by arrowhead servers. We connect to each other using our psn accounts, so you need to be logged in to play with other people. Its not bad but when problems start to occur such as weekends when you can't get a game and you've been looking forward to it all week, well that just leaves a bad taste in your mouth. We pay monthly money for our playstation plus service and they can't provide a server for a game they sold for free? Seriously? Like wtf Sony! This is cheap as, fact! Happily pulling in the dosh whilst providing minimial tech capital investment to look after you're customers and developers.

Prepare to get stomped. This game will show you new ways to die. That being said, when you get a great squad together it's a total blast. If you enjoy top down shooters, the teamwork in this game makes it worth picking up with some buddies.
Great game, but **** servers disconnecting every 10 minutes make it unbearable. Even if you are playing solo, it disconnects and sends you to the main menu. A real shame

People who are giving this game low scores, are criticizing it for the wrong reasons. They are complaining about manual reloading, not enough ammo, stratagem key combos etc. Are these guys for real? It is the formula on which this game thrives. It finds a great balance between strategizing and working as a team, and simply blowing sh*t up. I am quite far into the game and ammo has never really been an issue. It is simply about being able to prioritize your load out before going into a mission and which team member provides ammo drops and when. (To get my point across I am playing the game with my wife and four year old son) Having to key combo stratagems adds a level of intensity and challenge to the battlefield and quite honestly if they made it a one button action, it would make the game extremely boring.

Extremely fun, challenging and action packed online. Single player on the other hand is still all that minus some of the fun. Story would be so much better if I didn't have to read it half the time (I REALLY HATE READING IN VIDEO GAMES) This games is best played online in my opinion, you don't have to communicate if you don't want to!

Picked this up because it was free on PS Plus and for the most part, I've had a lot of fun with this game. I enjoy the strategic commands, something you don't usually see in a video game. However, matchmaking can be a pain and finding a match might take a while.

Fun, enjoyably re-playable, and casual but can also demand serious teamwork on harder levels. The matchmaking is easy (though often dangerous).  IF you like chaos and teamwork in a well-made shooter, go for it.

Awesome game that  It forces you to cooperate (local or online up to 4 players) in a way that is smart, funny and cruel at the same time, thanks to friendly fire and the fact that almost everything can kill you.

I've invested about 30 hours into the game its self and I'm still l'm still playing it now. It's delightfully addictive, simple, and fun. Seeing that I have little friends to who happen to own the game, I hop in the game with no mic. I found that the players you meet are very easy to communicate with due to the voice commands. Sharing a screen with the other players was also a great idea since it forces the players to work together. Couch co-op is also a blast as long as you're not playing with people below the age of 6 because kids can get a little... Team-killy? I had played with a six year old locally and 2 more people just so happened to join the game and he got mad that they were taking the ammo he couldn't pick up and killed us all xD
Great gameplay for casual gamer, big fun with friends, nice parody of Starship troopers :).

Amazing game!!! One of the best multiplayer AND co-op games in ps store. Lots of hilarious moments and almost the only thing I play in the ps vita right now (with wi-fi connection). Buy it! The more we log in, more interesting the game is. The DLC it's not needed.
Multiplayer game. The game is semi fun with a partner, other it is a pretty basic game, and I cant really say it did much for me. Felt very repetitive.
Fun, humorous, game in the vein of Starship Troopers meets Geometry Wars/Diablo with objectives. Perfect amount of difficulty to give you a challenge.

Helldivers is a very strong co-op game that’ll provide great thrills and challenges with your friends. There is something very satisfying about finally completing a difficult level, which I put down to the fluid gameplay that rewards teamwork over anything else.
This game is like crack! Addicting af.

This is quite a decent game, and I think it scores quite high in the world of the twin stick shooters. Its game play is significantly different from the average twin stick shooter (e.g. dead nation) in terms of it is not simple, crazy action fun. Mastering this game requires some careful playing, you need to coop well with the other players, think of the abilities/weapons that make sense in the team, be careful with your aim (mainly, but no uniquely, because of friendly fire) etc.. If you go all crazy john Rambo, you’ll die quite quickly. I think it is a nice different gameplay, but if you’re just looking for some crazy mayhem fun, maybe you wanna look somewhere else.
This is a really good top down twin stick like shooter. Really fun for playing with friends. It's well worth an investment on any system it's out for.

Easy to learn, very nice co-operation game. Playing with this game is so fun, but this isn't a game in which I could spend more than 10 hours. Repetitive missions and the customization of your avatar is quite limited. If you like playing with friends, this game will be very fun and good for you.
The idea of being of being a part of the big fight is cool but the impact you have on the galactic battle is so small that it has no impact and you are just wasting your time.

One of the all time best couch game! You can't go wrong if you are looking for a game to play with friends/family on the same screen! Unforgiving with the friendly fire (or friendly stomping) but so much fun gets you to communicate a lot with your team mates and there is a real sense of accomplishment when you manage to survive a tough map.

Helldivers is a game that shouldn't be as good as it is. My first impressions were of an utterly unremarkable twin-stick shooter. After hundreds of hours of gameplay, I can assure you that could not be further from the truth.

title: Her Majesty's SPIFFING
summary: Taking command of the near future spaceship HMSS Imperialise and her crew, you delve into the cosmos, solving puzzles, engaging in humourous banter, deal with crippling claustrophobia, gradually succumb to the sustained exposure of cosmic radiation, and so on. All for Queen and Country.
reviews: An interesting point 'n' click adventure that is fun but too short.
An endearingly goofy take on the Point-and-Click genre that revels in breaking the fourth wall with a stiff upper lip.
If you love graphic adventures and British sense of humor (shall we say 'humour'), you're going to have a great time with this.
An occasionally biting satire of post-Brexit Britain, that also happens to be one of the best – and shortest – graphic adventures of 2016.
A Point'n'click adventure depicting a wacky crew of two, exploring nearby systems for the British empire to colonize.

title: Here They Lie
summary: Here They Lie is a psychological horror experience that injects you into a frightening, surreal world riddled with strange and malevolent creatures. Horrors lurk around every corner, just out of sight, haunting and infecting your mind. Dare yourself to go deeper down the rabbit hole and confront the meaning of your existence. The game focuses on narrative, and the experience of dread. [Tangentlemen]
reviews: Screaming creatures, cities on fire, underground stations that warp and shudder like an intestine, and a humanoid pig giving an antelope a high-five as they tag team a CRT television. What’s not to love?
Here They Lie is grotesque and horrifying, but it’s also a thought-provoking, philosophical head trip that makes some of the best use of VR to date.

Its enigmatic visuals, choice-driven narrative, and provocations on morality are the driving forces that warrant multiple playthroughs, and all of those aforementioned elements combine to make Here They Lie one of the standout offerings among the PSVR's launch lineup.

While the story of what happens to the main characters is unfulfilling, the descent into the hellish world of Here They Lie is, on its own, worth taking. Its dreary, evocative environments, dark tone, and horrific imagery would stand out even outside the realm of VR games. Some of its places, acts, and monsters will stick with me for a while. It creates a strong sense of place, and while I wouldn't say VR is crucial to experience, it definitely amplifies it.
Here They Lie is without a doubt one of the most traumatic experiences we've ever had in videogames. We dove deep into the horror, and only the motion sickness got us back out of VR.
A walking simulator with a disturbing and unique atmosphere, but also with a limited gameplay and basic and poor graphics.

Horror is a very natural fit for the technology, but some awkward juxtapositions between Here They Lie’s art direction and theming, and the critical lack of physical feedback after providing such a sensory overload in other ways, is perhaps an argument that the best horror experiences we’ll see on VR will be the “walking simulators” that focus on psychological fear rather than physical threats.

Here They Lie is a clever game for the PlayStation VR and its motion sickness does make wonder whether this game would be better suited for the PS4 Pro for faster framerates. The game’s momentum starts slow and every now and then the game will really make you jump which is where the developers have succeeded. However in terms of gameplay, it is a little light in its nature but the nonetheless is an interesting look into both the horror genre and into the psyche of the main character in this horror thriller.

I’ll be honest; by the time Here They Lie’s credits rolled, I still didn’t really have a firm grasp of what it was all about… All I know is that it kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish.

An engaging surrealist horror that is elevated by some great sound design and a wonderfully nihilistic setting, Here They Lie might not change up the formula too much but it remains an effective PSVR scare-a-thon that you don't want to leave in the ground.
The developers care more about affecting your mind and controlling your emotions than they do about your physical ability to complete their slice of grim fantasy.

Here They Lie is not a perfect horror game – but it's tense and well worth experiencing if you're looking for some frights for your new PlayStation VR headset. The narrative could have been stronger, and the way it displays textures is odd, but the cavernous environments and clever control scheme make this a ride worth taking.

Here They Lie is a disturbing psychological thriller, the digitization of a nightmare. The gaming experience is, for this reason, interesting and meaningful. Much of the credit goes to the virtual reality headset, which transforms this disturbing Walking Simulator in a hellish journey.

As a PSVR launch title from a new development studio, Here They Lie impressed me. Tangentlemen have good ideas, atmosphere and sound design, but ultimately the meandering pacing and sporadic story beats of their work left me feeling more disappointed than scared. I’ll be keeping my eyes on these developers, though — if this is what they deliver for their debut game, I’m eager to see what they serve up next.

There are wonderfully horrifying moments and some lovely little details, but they’re too few and far between – and getting to them is an exercise in resilience rather than pleasure. [January 2016, p77]
A nightmarish virtual reality world that scares and sickens in equal measure. [Christmas 2016, p.86]
Horror elements are overcooked and, alongside seriously limited interactions, lead to a game that’s not half as frightening as it thinks it is.
Daring and provocative, but also poorly written and technically inept. PlayStation VR will no doubt get much better horror games in the future, but this is still a notable first step.
A psychological horror experience blended with a walking simulator that will make you ask for an antiemetic.
A nice idea that does not work due to its repetitiveness and because it can cause (a lot) of nausea.

With Here They Lie, I stared long and hard into the abyss, only this time it didn’t stir; instead, I was left gazing at an under-cooked horror experience that while surreal, fails to deliver a fulfilling end product. Horror games should present an exercise in nerve-shredding tension whether they’re built for virtual reality or not. Sadly, Here They Lie leans too heavily on VR as a novelty to justify a by-the-numbers entry into the genre.
Here They Lie offers a strong atmosphere and can be really terrifying. The only problems are the poor graphics and above all the fact that it will make you sick very quickly in VR.

Here They Lie is a successful use of the PlayStation VR, but outside of the novelty of transporting yourself into the veil of a unique hellish landscape created by beautifully tortured souls, the actual delivery and writing fall flat.

This is definitely the weirdest title in the PSVR launch lineup. Sometimes an impressive showing of how immersive and claustrophobic horror in virtual can be, mechanically most of the time it is just not interesting enough. Plus there is a decent issue of motion sickness that even hardened VR players might succumb to.
It offers everything we look forward and everything that we fear about virtual reality. It's a charismatic game, but certainly confusing and opaque.

At first, Here They Lie is quite the scarefest. Unfortunately, this sense of creepiness doesn't last long. In the end, Here They Lie is a confusing walking simulator that simply doesn't offer enough in terms of depth or content to deserve your hard-earned money.

Here They Lie is not the VR-horror game that it could have been. While is does have some tense moments, the technical imperfections and vague storytelling spoil most of the fun. Because of that, Here They Lie is not a blast to play through.

The best I can say of it is that it’s left me curious as to what might come next. If nothing else, it illustrates how the unparalleled immersive properties of virtual reality make possible some truly unsettling interactive horror experiences...Now someone needs to create a horror game that’s not just scary, but also fun to play and has a good story.
Here They Lie manages to create a succesfull sick atmosphere; the problem is that the player will get motion-sickness far too early in the game to really enjoy it or even finish it.
The first true horror game for PlayStation VR is an unpleasant and revolting experience. But not for the reasons you are thinking.
A surreal horror game sounds like a good idea on paper but the predictability of the scenes and the atrocious & nauseating camera movement makes this game an dull, discomforting experience.

Predictable jump scares, ringing telephones, spooky notes, guys in animal masks humping things and malfunctioning flashlights litter the landscape, and with each new instance, you’re left less and less impressed.

Here They Lie smacks of cynicism – a game designed with the knowledge that horror works really well in VR, without anybody involved knowing how VR games should operate. It’s distinctly unpleasant to play, and I fear it’ll be only one of many horror games that pull the same stunt as virtual reality continues to hold sway.

I am giving this a 10 for the simple fact, that it does what it is supposed to do....it scares the crap out of you. it is not an action game or anything of the sort, you are simply walking through, finding some clues/notes here and there, but holy crap there are some really scary moments.

The best VR game on playstation vr right now. I dont get all the people screaming motion sickness, me and my friend played it - our first vr experience ever - and we were both fine as we sat for 4 hours the first session.

So I know next to nothing about horror games next to Bioshock. On a VR level this hit all the right spots for me...granted I needed to work though this in fits and spurts (because I'm kinda chicken). But nonetheless I absolutely loved the atmosphere and narrative. Fun experience for twenty bucks.
Coming in as one of the options of the lineup for the VR launch, Here That Lie represents a strong contender for your pleasure.

If you like your games scary then this is for you. It has the jump scares you are expecting to occur and many that are unexpected and these really get you. The story is so so but enjoyable enough. However it's the VR experience that this game excels in. You will have a sense of immersion and if you are like me and have played all the horror / thriller games out there, the sense of walking in one is great. Lastly the motion sickness. This game will bring on those sweats that you dread, however this can be over come by walking in straight lines and using the quarter turn function rather than your head motion where possible and building up on your sessions. That is true for most VR games I'm finding (except drive club) so bare with it, build on it and enjoy the twisted world that's on offer.

While the graphics are low rez in VR this kinda lends itself to the atmosphere in a weird kind of way.. meaning that you can't quite make out what that 'thing' is moving in the distance and that makes you feel more uncomfortable.

Induces VR sickness ... probably aggravated from left and right eye being badly synchronized with regards to lightening and possibly perspective. Run demo, do you have sensation view fields have dark smudges, then alternate between closing left and right eye and you'll see ... one eye sees bright the other sees dark when looking at same area. THIS IS REALLY BAD - Sony must step up and forbid this kind of ****
Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit Vomit
After 10 minutes of play is cause massive motion sickness for hours...

I am the best critic in the world. Everybody buys things solely based on my opinion as I have the reputation. With that in mind, I created a name here so I can write a review on the game. By far the worst part about it is it will make you sick. Some people after I min, some after 5, etc. By the time 30 minutes comes around 90 percent of people playing have to put it down and they feel sick. The graphics are crap. The controls are crap. Everything is the biggest piece of crap I've ever seen. San Andreas, Vice City, resident evil 4 are my three favorite games. Thus I know what I'm talking about. You just walk and walk and you just sick. It's torture. They should make people that commit sex crimes play this game over and over. I gave it a 1 BECAUSE I love the way the bad guys look in the game. I like how they use sound effects to make the game more eerie. This is the only review that should matter on this game.
An expensive 3 hours of linear so called horror, garbled story line, and a total disappointment to boot.
Graphics: 6.0 Sound: 5.0 Gameplay: 6.5 Fun/Story: 6.2   VR mode analysis

the graphic motion and visual graphic in this game is really low. game is really short in a way that after 2 hours you finish this game very soon. if I compare this game with other VR games I don't agree with these sort of games. this should be more attractive and fantastic. but, the artistic aspect about this game is a good idea. if you have artistic mind toward everything I suggest this game to you, you need to think about background thoughts beyond what you see in this game.Totally this game cannot draw attention to every one.

title: Hidden Agenda
summary: Blending the best elements of movies and games, this story-based adventure drops you into a tale rife with chilling moral dilemmas.
reviews: As I said up top, there are certainly reasons to be wary of Hidden Agenda. It’s hard not to search a crime scene for clues with your unresponsive PlayLink app and come away wishing that you were just using a plain controller. But that’s more than outweighed by the fact that the game also does a better job of capturing what makes mystery novels so compelling than nearly anything else I’ve ever played. Hidden Agenda may not be perfect, but it knows how to keep you hooked right to the very end.

Innovative, Original, satisfying. Supermassive Games knows how to create interactive stories and proves it with a very interesting title that you and your friends can play together or against each other.

Hidden Agenda is like stepping into a crime drama and influencing how it plays out. The branching narrative is a welcoming aspect and makes me want to play it multiple times. It's fun to play alone, but taking it on with friends is a treat all on it's own.

Hidden Agenda is an innovative experience that opens up new possibilities in the world of interactive adventures. The title of SuperMassive Games proposes us live a party of crime with friends and influence all together in the history. It is not perfect, but it is a great alternative for entertainment.

Games like Hidden Agenda are what we need to see more of. The game itself isn’t perfect, but it is a perfect example of games that try new ways to tell a story. Full credit to Sony for trying something new with the mobile phone linking system.
Hidden Agenda is a great thriller, where players are determined to determine the outcome of the story.

Hidden Agenda shows the success of PlayLink. A game developed by Supermassive Games that gathers the best of Until Dawn with a dark story with some funny moments. Great to play with family and friends, since it can have 6 simultaneous players.
Supermassive Games brings players another unique adventure in the multiplayer, action-adventure, thriller Hidden Agenda.

There are so many things you can do differently over the course of the story, and the game has incredible replay value. And should you ever get tired of replaying the same mystery, you could always invite a few friends over for an intense night of distrust and suspicion.

As someone who has grown increasingly wary of the rote formula most modern adventure games cling to, Hidden Agenda is another fresh and worthwhile experience from Supermassive. It may not have the same impact or polish as its predecessor, but it provides an evening of solid entertainment and a great alternative to the standard choose-your-own-adventure fare.
Hidden Agenda is a couch co-op adventure game played with a smartphone. It has some narrative issues, but was still fun to play with friends.

In spite of a few story weaknesses, Hidden Agenda is a very good interactive movie that makes a cleaver use of the PlayLink technology by allowing multiple players to join in. A perfect pick for an evening with non-gamer friends, but we would have loved a bit more interaction, while the app uses a lot of energy from your phone.
A very interesting interactive movie with a very distinctive party game on it. A true achievement for Supermassive Games.

Hidden Agenda isn't very deep, but it's a fun and creative game that you're going to want to share with all of your friends. It's an interesting showcase of making a typical adventure title into a party experience that takes advantage of the PlayStation’s PlayLink platform.
Not exactly family-friendly Christmas fare, but definitely worth a look with friends. [Christmas 2017, p.60]
A somewhat embarrassed and mechanical, cooperative and competitive script that sometimes clashes with the thoughtful, reflective and weighted nature typical of an interactive thriller.
Hidden Agenda is a nice interactive thriller, but it lacks finetuning regarding story and gameplay mechanics.
It's doing something different as part of Play Link, and there is no better studio to do a crime story using this service, even though some of the gameplay elements are a bit dull.

Playlink doesn’t get enough credit. At first it seemed like PlayStation simply trying to get on the Jackbox bandwagon, but they seem to be invested in the program and it’s working out well for them. Supermassive has done impressive things with the technology and thought of a new way to take advantage of it. Hidden Agenda tells a good story and is great for a fun night in with friends. It has problems in the graphics and writing areas, but it’s a fun and entertaining game in the end. $19.99 is a great value for the quality of the content throughout the five chapters and it signals exiting things to come for Playlink.

Hidden Agenda is a game built to be played with friends, but ultimately I found the most fun in single player. It is also a game made to be finished in one sitting, but I grew to like it more after two playthroughs. Wrapping the adventure up in the guise of a party game does it no favours, but it proficiently overcomes these issues to be a worthwhile experience. I’d love to see this series have another outing, and hope for a more ambitious sequel if it were to continue.
A movie dressed like a videogame that fails to retain your attention once you have completed it... And it only lasts for two hours.
As an interactive movie, you could do a lot worse than Hidden Agenda. However, technical issues and a number of unsatisfying endings are flaws that deserve to be mentioned.

I wish Hidden Agenda was more of a traditional PS4 game rather than a PlayLink gimmick. Still, with a solid (yet slightly predictable storyline; at least, the one I played through), it’s well worth a go. Supermassive is quickly becoming my favourite Sony developer.

Hidden Agenda tells us an interesting story, and adds a new type of game to the PlayLink lineup, but unfortunately, it's quite short and not very replayable, considering it is part of a set of games designed to be played with friends.

If you love choose-your-own-adventure games, Hidden Agenda is compelling enough to make for an evening’s entertainment, especially given its price – but it feels more a glimpse of what could be enabled by mobile-connected games in the future, than a showcase of them at the moment.

Technical hurdles can be frustrating to overcome, and there’s very little replay value with the same group of people, but if you regularly host friends and family, even those who don’t play games much, Hidden Agenda makes for a surprising and enjoyable evening.
Hidden Agenda is a great concept with some impressive set pieces and performances, but its narrative lets it down and it lacks any major impact.
Hidden Agenda is a funny - but very short - cinematic adventure game with a lot of QTE and social features, available only for PlayLink users.

Hidden Agenda is a hard recommendation, because the game feels like a natural fit to share with non-gamers, but we had one playthrough that ended so abruptly and unsatisfyingly I thought we had somehow skipped a section, and had I brought this game out at a party I would have felt like we totally wasted two hours. With the right group (like people who understand that if you don’t do well at a game you lose) it’s enjoyable, provided you have the time available to finish it in one sitting. Ultimately the game rests more on a few short action sequences than it does on the decisions made, which undercuts the experience and contributes to Hidden Agenda falling short of its potential.

Hidden Agenda is definitely a first, interesting step towards the consecration of Playlink. The work done by the creators of Until Dawn is certainly interesting at the conceptual level, even though they have not reached high peaks. The road is still long.

With a huge web of choices to make and an enjoyable competitive mode to boot, there’s a lot to like in this crime analysis. Hidden Agenda proves that the PlayLink initiative can be taken advantage of in more than just casual party games, but this particular outing doesn’t quite realise its full potential. This investigation is absolutely one worth experiencing, but one too many caveats with the app itself holds things back from greatness.

As a game for chilling out on the sofa with a handful of friends or the family, Hidden Agenda is pretty cool. Yet there’s a lot about the mechanics, the story, the situations and the characters that seems wilfully, crazily dumb. For £20 for a few hours of fun it’s well worth a try, but this feels like an interesting concept that needs some work before it all comes good.

It's clear that Hidden Agenda has an interesting concept. But this interactive thriller playable with your phone doesn't really fit with the idea of a party game and sometimes feels a bit rushed in technical terms and not really memorable.

While the PlayLink technology has potential and does some really cool things by turning your phone into a controller, it also adds unnecessary complications to a game that uses the second screen functionality as more of a gimmick than a core gameplay mechanic. Hidden Agenda is a good game, but is held back from being great by trying to fit it into the party game mold.

Hidden Agenda is a gritty and intriguing experience that should entertain up to six players for about the length of the average movie. It isn't without its flaws though, and most likely won't be something you'll play more than once.

Hidden Agenda fails to deliver on its potential. The game makes some poor design choices, making it hard to fall in love with this game. Hidden Agenda, nevertheless, gives hope for more non-party PlayLink games.

Hidden Agenda is a pleasant narrative with some interesting ideas that don’t exactly pan out. It falls short of the high mark set by Until Dawn, but give points to Supermassive for trying something new instead of pumping out a clone of their last game. That said, I wanted another Until Dawn. In a densely packed genre, there are plenty of titles players should look into before considering Hidden Agenda.
Subject matter that doesn't suit a party game, and writing that isn't worthy of a budget thriller. [Jan 2018, p.78]

The competitive mode is fine, but the rest of the game is not. It’s short (no unnecessary background-building scenes whatsoever), the characters are just shallow cut-outs, the choices seem meaningless and on top of all I experienced some technical issues. [01/2018, p.64]
It lacks any substantial cause of replayability after a couple of runs, but still has an impressively malleable string of events that transcend other titles in the genre. [Issue#195, p.78]

There’s some good ideas in how PlayLink can be used to let a group of players (and non-gamers in particular) join together and shape a filmic story, but the actual interface feels clumsy, and the story and scripting leaves plenty to be desired. It’s safe to say that Hidden Agenda is an obvious disappointment.
It's a laugh, albeit at the expense of itself. [Issue#314, p.118]
In single-player or multiplayer, Hidden Agenda is a game in which winning almost always feels like losing.

The animations are superb and the story is very well planned. however, the endings besides the main ending seem very premature and some times the game is over without any sign and many questions remain unanswered. It is very painful that you are unable to continue your story via chapter selection.

I must praise this game despite the clunky mobile controls and underwhelming graphics.  The player is given many options that aren't always readily apparent which is best course to match the ultimate ending you may be trying to achieve.  The diverging stories seem to be way more numerous than Until Dawn. Some story lines feel more fleshed out than others and some jumps from scene to scene feel more or less natural than a full price game should feel which sometimes feel as characters make radical jumps in logic that won't be clear till a 2nd or 3rd play but with 2 plays as of this review their are radically different directions the story may go.  This is a highly entertaining narrative while not the most original plot... I have to question why the devs didn't make this a full length game as it would have been labeled best of the year however the short length is sure to keep this title from getting the AAA attention it deserves.

Para os amantes do gênero suspense, Hidden Agenda é indispensável! Gráficos impecáveis, história envolvente e uma ótima dublagem. Parabéns a SuperMassive Games por ter inovado o mercado de jogos com esse novo título, onde é possível se divertir com até 5 amigos no mesmo ambiente utilizando seus smartphones, coisa que falta nos dias de hoje (modo cooperativo local). Além disso, o custo benefício vale muito a pena por mais que o jogo seja relativamente curto. Nota 10!

Even though it is not an expensive game, it is not worth what you pay. I played it with one other person in competitive mode, and despite having a nice concept, Hidden Agenda does not deliver a good experience, since when you are getting the hang of the game it ends.
O jogo é divertido quando você junta uma galera, lembrando que você pode usar seu smartphone se você gostou do Until dawn é uma boa pedida já que é no mesmo clima.

Short but sweet. You can roughly  beat this game in 2HRS. So a sitting. The story has to be good here with barely any interaction, and I am happy to say it is. The story is engaging, but it can be better. The game isn't as good as Until Dawn, but I think this does have a audience. But I do feel this is gonna get heavy riducled with "this isn't a game, it's a movie" and I am usually one of the people who defend these games, but with this one I really can't because it really is that. The game is fun and is meant to play multiple times to get all the different storylines, so you can probably get about 5HRS or so in this. The writing is really goo d and the voice acting is good for the most part, except for some lines here and there were a little off. The addition to the party system is really cool, but I don't think a lot of people will really do t his and the multiplayer component is pretty cool as well. But all in all if you like the interactive games you will find enjoyment out of this.

Hidden Agenda is essentially a scaled back version of Until Dawn. Though the game runs a bit short at around 2 hours (as little as 45 minutes if you really mess up), it makes up for that with far more endings and alternate scenes than it's predecessor. Basically, they took out the needless walking, removed all except for the most important choices and streamlined the interface (although I marked it down from an 8 to a 7 because of the lack of DualShock4 support). Overall, it is a fun, if sometimes corny, crime drama That will keep you entertained for at least 3 or 4 playthroughs, even more if you play it with friends to see what kind of outcome they get. 7/10
-GAME REQUIRES A SMART PHONE TO PLAY. Using an app through the smartphone, it as as a controller to select choices with finger swipes. Often jerky and hard to detect on PS4.

This game is a waste of 20 bucks. I mean the storyline is good and you can control the whole outcome of the game but you can't control your player such as walking through areas, driving, the typical control your character persona. The whole game is based on making decisions and you have to download a b.s app to play, no use of your controller what so ever.

It's fun, obviously meant to be played with friends. Arguing about the choices and tricking others is much more fun than the actual gameplay, and clearly the game is built that way. Finally, party games are coming back!
A really big disappointment.  Gameplay was very limited and choices felt very meaningless and obvious.  Acting was very dry, stiff, and boring.  Waste of money.
Short but catchy, graphics look good and the story keeps you wanting more, phone controllers is a good idea but it shouldn't be the only choice of controllers. Other than that it is all good.

Я просто в восторге. Интерактивное кинцо - обожаю, супермассив гейм - великолепные истории. Это именно тот случай когда ты не можешь оторваться от происходящего на экране. Игра отлично ложится в разряд тех игр в которые нужно играть на консоли. Фишка с телефоном забавная крайне. Да она не длинная, это жалко но и стоит полцены. Всем владельцам PS4 обязательна к покупке!

I have played many games in this genre (cinematic/choice driven games) and Hidden Agenda does the best job out of any game with story layout and choices.  The details and the small dialogue options really matter, not in stupid, unforeseen ways but in ways that actually make sense.  It was innovative and genius to add a cooperative or competitive element to this type of game play and I really hope we see more of this in the future. Hidden Agenda really brings a social element into play by asking teammates to pick: "who is the most observant among you?" and then forcing that person to make a decision alone that hinges upon how observant they actually are.  On the first playthrough, the story may seem rushed at times, but this is something you are grateful for on subsequent playthroughs.  The story sticks to what is necessary for the plot and really cuts down on any narrative overtones or bridges.  Despite this, they do a good job at creating some pretty fleshed out characters in such a short time.

Really enjoyed playing through with other people. That's the key, you need other people to enjoy it to the fullest. It's innovative. The story kept us all guessing until the end. Sure, it's terrible compared to a TV show or movie in terms of pacing, plotlines, plotholes and a rushed ending, but the interactivity pulls you along.

title: Hidden Dragon Legend
summary: Hidden Dragon is a 2.5D action platformer set in Imperial China, combining classic platform action with fast-paced combo fighting, harkening back to classics like Ninja Gaiden, Devil May Cry, and Shinobi.
reviews: At 20 dollars, it is a tough ask as a purchase since this developer with no discernible track record in the west. Those who take the leap will find a rather solid title with high replayability and a visual style seldom seen on our shores. One can only hope that the publisher can put some more marketing dollars towards this title so that it can find some sort of audience.
Ultimately, Hidden Dragon: Legend is a fairly average beat-em-up/platformer, but its sky-high production values and sheer love of spectacle is sure to delight players.

Hidden Dragon Legend is not a terrible game, and it does try hard at times. Some decent art design and combat mechanics offer the potential for a bit of enjoyment. However, it doesn’t present enough variation in gameplay to stay fresh, and the combat – a major part of the game – begins to break down when things get hectic. Irritation, frustration, and maybe boredom will begin to seep in after the initial fun, making this platforming adventure less than legendary.

A middle-of-the-road effort: there are certainly a number of people out there who will be able to work through its less-than-polished mechanics long enough to enjoy the silly story, which is reminiscent of classic Chinese action cinema in the best possible ways. Then there will be folks who fall on the other side of the fence, without the patience to deal with the slightly clunky controls and dark, slightly muddied aesthetic.

In general it's a mediocre game, with a gameplay that only has some good moments. Although the combat system can hook a little, the inconsequential phases of platforms and repetitive clashes will cause you to lose patience before exceeding half of their levels.

Hidden Dragon Legend’s cover art should appear in any search engine’s results for mixed bag. The combat it offers is challenging and genuinely fun, but the traversal that comes between it is far too often broken and unfair. As you run through Imperial China, you’ll be enchanted by the mood, only to be brought right back out by stiff cutscenes and terribly compressed weapon sounds. Upon reflection, I truly believe that MegaFun Games put real passion into this project, though; even the elements that don't work are laid out in a way where they'd be very enjoyable if they did. It's just a shame that the finished project is so deeply flawed.
Hidden Dragon Legend tries to do more than it can truly do. The combat system is deep but with too many problems, many game sections are frustrating and the game has overall bad animations.

It’s the frustrating sort of hard that comes about because of poor mechanics rather than elegant design. Despite your demon powers, the rules of this particular fight club start off by declaring that they’re going to be totally different for you and your enemies.
Hidden Dragon Legend offers a feast of combat action and platforming with a beefy challenge but comes with a host of irritations too.

Hidden Dragon: Legend is an indie title that offers an initial burst of satisfying combat, but that quickly devolves into a tedious stream of identikit encounters coupled with platforming that feels like a tacked-on afterthought.

Hidden Dragon Legend is the classic example of a game trying to be bigger than it’s potential budget or development. There is a great idea here marred by too many issues for me to really recommend this to anyone except the hardcore action or indie supporters. There is fun to be had, but it comes with serious caveats.

Hidden Dragon isn’t terrible, but it’s sorely stuck not one, but two generations in the past. The sidescroller is by no means dead, yet those working in this shrinking subgenre are either emulating its most celebrated champions or pushing the boundaries with something new and inventive. Hidden Dragon does neither, nor does it have the visual oomph that can often help overlook a game’s shortcomings.

Hidden Dragon Legend has some good visual design but not much else, and it’s a shame. I appreciated the style, but the actual game is so shoddily produced that it’s impossible to enjoy. I don’t care that enemies look good if fighting them is sluggish and repetitive. With tighter controls and fluid combat, Hidden Dragon Legend could have been a minor gem, but it’s just an attractive failure.
Repetitive, technically cheap. Awful story and english dubbing, ridiculously high priced for what it offers. stay away from this game and maybe Oasis Games'll stop making disturbing software.

And Oasis Games' streak of mediocre chinese games still continues. I expected this game to be fantastic since the trailer showed a lot of promise. Sadly, it wasn't.
